    Installation_and_configuration Ngme2 Models

    Installation_and_configuration

    Installation_and_configuration.Rmd

    The default C++ compiler in OS X has does not support OpenMP.

    ➜ clang -fopenmp hello.cpp
clang: error: unsupported option '-fopenmp'

    In order to make use of OpenMP to enable multi-threading in OS X, we need to use compilers which supports OpneMP.

    1. Install a OpenMP supported clang as default C/C++ compiler.

    That’s why we need to install another compiler which supports OpenMP. Here I use homebrew for installing llvm clang compiler using the following scripts. (Check here homebrew or you can just run the following command to install homebrew.)

    /bin/bash -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Homebrew/install/HEAD/install.sh)"

    If successful, you should be able to see the following prompt.

    ➜ brew install llvm

...
To use the bundled libc++ please add the following LDFLAGS:
  LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/llvm/lib/c++ -Wl,-rpath,/usr/local/opt/llvm/lib/c++"

llvm is keg-only, which means it was not symlinked into /usr/local,
because macOS already provides this software and installing another version in
parallel can cause all kinds of trouble.

If you need to have llvm first in your PATH, run:
  echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/llvm/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

For compilers to find llvm you may need to set:
  export LDFLAGS="-L/usr/local/opt/llvm/lib"
  export CPPFLAGS="-I/usr/local/opt/llvm/include"

    To make the llvm clang default compiler, we need to update the PATH variable, and then reopen the terminal to make it work:

    ➜ echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/opt/llvm/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc

    Now we should be able to use the llvm clang with OpenMP support. Let’s test it:

    ➜ clang -fopenmp hello.cpp

    In my case, the llvm lib and include folder are already added into the default clang search path. (You can check the search path by run commands like clang hello.cpp -v, otherwise you may need to include mannually by -L and -I, you can also export it as system variable as suggested, then use makefile to compile).

    2. Configure the R environment to make use of the new compiler.

    Next if we want to use OpenMP in our R code (maybe exported it as R function using Rcpp package), we should make sure R to call our new compiler, not the original one. To do this, we can mannually set the Makeconf file (makefile configuration for R) in $R_HOME/etc/Makeconf.

    Here you can check the R_HOME address using R.home() in R termnial.

    R.home()
    ## [1] "/Library/Frameworks/R.framework/Resources"

    In my case, the R called compiler is still the default clang, so I explicitly replace it. Replace the configuration lines with following (where llvm clang is installed):

    CC = /usr/local/opt/llvm/bin/clang
CXX = /usr/local/opt/llvm/bin/clang++
CXX11 = $(CXX)
CXX14 = $(CXX)
CXX17 = $(CXX)
CXX20 = $(CXX)

    Now we should be able to export an OpenMP function in R using Rcpp.

    3. Configure the R package environment.

    If you are developing a R package using Rcpp, then you still need to make more efforts in the R package environment.

    1. Set OpenMP flags in R Makeconf

    Do not directly setting -fopenmp flag in Makevar file, it would be not portable to the system with no OpenMP support. It’s better to include it in the R Makeconf file. You can find the following two flags in Makeconf file.

    SHLIB_OPENMP_CFLAGS = -fopenmp
SHLIB_OPENMP_CXXFLAGS = -fopenmp
    1. Set package flags in package Makevar

    Next we can include this flag in the Makevar as following:

    PKG_CXXFLAGS = $(SHLIB_OPENMP_CXXFLAGS)
PKG_LIBS = $(SHLIB_OPENMP_CXXFLAGS)
    1. Set symbols in package Namespace

    One important thing next is to indicate you useDynLib(yourPackage) in the Namespace. You can either do it by yourself, or do it using devtools package for you.

    Edit the NAMESPACE file to create R objects for the registered symbols:

    useDynLib(yourPackage, .registration = TRUE)

    Or add #' @useDynLib yourPackage, .registration = TRUE it into yourPackage.R file, then run

    devtools::document()

    Then you should be able to see the update in your NAMESPACE file.

    Now you can have the OpenMP facility in your C++ code!
